references: We present more detailed results for fine-tuning hyperparameters, including methods without a global model, in TablesÂ II toÂ V. Here, Eğ¸E represents the number of edge servers in the hierarchical framework, and Î±ğ›¼\alpha represents the proportion of the client model that does not interact with the global model in HeurFedAMP. For HeurFedAMP, we tune Î±âˆˆ[0.1,0.5]ğ›¼0.10.5\alpha\in[0.1,0.5], where Î±ğ›¼\alpha represents the proportion of the client model that does not interact with the global model. For Fedprox, we tune Î»âˆˆ{0.001,0.01,0.1,1}ğœ†0.0010.010.11\lambda\in\{0.001,0.01,0.1,1\} following the setting in [18]. For pFedMe and sFedHP, we use the same setting as in [19] with Î»âˆˆ{5,15,20,25,30}ğœ†515202530\lambda\in\{5,15,20,25,30\}. For pFedGP, we use the same setting as in [22] for other basic hyperparameters. We find that sFedHP outperforms all compared algorithms in the global model (GM) and achieves state-of-the-art results in the personalized model (PM).

Fig.Â 2 shows the performance of sFedHP, hierarchical FedAvg and pFedMe in Î¼ğœ‡\mu-strongly convex situation. Since the MLR model is already lightweight enough, we set Î³1=Î³2=0subscriptğ›¾1subscriptğ›¾20\gamma_{1}=\gamma_{2}=0 for sFedHP. In Fig.Â 2, we can see that both sFedHP and pFedMe perform better than hierarchical FedAvg, while sFedHP obtain higher test accuracy and convergence speed, which shows that the hierarchical personalization scheme is more suitable for solving statistical diversity problem.

In summary, sFedHP performs better that pFedMe and hierarchical FedAvg in test accuracy, convergence rate, and communication cost in Î¼ğœ‡\mu-strongly convex and nonconvex situations. Furthermore, the hierarchical personalization scheme is more suitable for solving statistical diversity problems.

clients and assign each client a unique local data with only 5 out of 10 labels. For client-edge-cloud framework, we set 4 edge servers and each edge server manages 5 clients. All 20 clients are selected to generate the global model in following experiments.

Furthermore, we use two different dataset split settings to validate the performance of the above algorithms. In Setting 1, we used 200, 200, 100 training samples and 800, 800, 400 test samples in each class for MNIST, FMNIST and CIFAR-10 datasets respectively. In Setting 2, 900, 900, 450 training samples and 300, 300, 150 test samples are applied on MNIST, FMNIST and CIFAR-10 datasets for each class. We use the DNN model with two hidden layers of size [500, 200] for MNIST/FMNIST datasets and the VGG model for CIFAR-10 dataset with â€œ[16, â€˜Mâ€™, 32, â€˜Mâ€™, 64 â€˜Mâ€™, 128, â€˜Mâ€™, 128, â€˜Mâ€™]â€ cfg setting. clients and assign each client a unique local data with only 5 out of 10 labels. For client-edge-cloud framework, we set 4 edge servers and each edge server manages 5 clients. All 20 clients are selected to generate the global model in following experiments.

Furthermore, we use two different dataset split settings to validate the performance of the above algorithms. In Setting 1, we used 200, 200, 100 training samples and 800, 800, 400 test samples in each class for MNIST, FMNIST and CIFAR-10 datasets respectively. In Setting 2, 900, 900, 450 training samples and 300, 300, 150 test samples are applied on MNIST, FMNIST and CIFAR-10 datasets for each class. We use the DNN model with two hidden layers of size [500, 200] for MNIST/FMNIST datasets and the VGG model for CIFAR-10 dataset with â€œ[16, â€˜Mâ€™, 32, â€˜Mâ€™, 64 â€˜Mâ€™, 128, â€˜Mâ€™, 128, â€˜Mâ€™]â€ cfg setting. Each experiment is run at least 3 times to obtain statistical reports.

We found that hierarchical federated learning methods, such as sFedHP and HierFAVG, significantly outperformed other federated learning methods, including FedAvg, FedProx, and pFedMe, in the device-cloud structure on non-i.i.d. data.
